description: Topic C includes lessons 12-16 and covers describing the center of a distribution using the median, describing variability using the interquartile range (IQR), summarizing a distribution using a box plot, more practice with box plots, and understanding box plots.

title: Topic G: Solving equations
description:
Topic G includes lessons 23-29 and covers true and false number sentences, finding solutions to make equations true, one-step equations, two-step problems, and multi-step problems.

(Currently, we do not have content for Lessons 28 and 29.)

title: Topic C: Volume of right rectangular prisms
description: Topic C includes lessons 11-14 and covers volume with fractional edge lengths and unit cubes, from unit cubes to the formulas for volume, the formulas for volume, and volume in the real world.

title: Topic D: Nets and surface area
description: Topic D includes lessons 15-19 and covers representing three-dimensional figures using nets, constructing nets, from nets to surface area, determining surface area of three-dimensional figures, surface area and volume in the real world.

title: Interpreting graphs of proportional relationships
description: Learn how to read and understand graphs of proportional relationships

title: Topic D: Summarizing and describing distributions
description:
Topic D includes lessons 17-22 and covers developing a statistical project, connecting graphical representations and numerical summaries, comparing data distributions, describing center, variability, and shape of a data distribution from a graphical representation, summarizing a data distribution by describing center, variability, and shape, and presenting a summary of a statistical project.

(Currently, we do not have content for Lesson 22.)

title: Topic C: Ratios and rates involving fractions
description:
Topic C includes lessons 11-15 and covers ratios of fractions and their unit rates, finding equivalent ratios given the total quantity, multi-step ratio problems, and equations and graphs of proportional relationships involving fractions.

(Currently, we do not have content for Lessons 11 and 14.)

title: Topic D: Ratios of scale drawings
description: Topic D includes lessons 16-22 and covers relating scale drawings to ratios and rates, the unit rate as the scale factor, computing actual lengths from a scale drawing, computing actual areas from a scale drawing, an exercise in creating a scale drawing, and an exercise in changing scales.

title: Topic A: Addition and subtraction of integers and rational numbers
description: Topic A includes lessons 1-9 and covers opposite quantities combine to make zero, using the number line to model the addition of integers, understanding addition of integers, efficiently adding integers and other rational numbers, understanding subtraction of integers and other rational numbers, the distance between two rational numbers, addition and subtraction of rational numbers, and applying the properties of operations to add and subtract rational numbers.

title: Topic H: Applications of equations
description: Topic H includes lessons 30-34 and covers one-step problems in the real world, problems in mathematical terms, multi-step problems in the real world, from equations to inequalities, and writing and graphing inequalities in real-world problems.

title: Identifying scale factors
description: Sal looks at a figure and a scale copy of the figure to determine what scale factor was used to create the scale copy.

title: Topic A: Use properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions
description: Topic A includes lessons 1-6 and covers generating equivalent expressions, writing products as sums and sums as products, using the identity and inverse to write equivalent expressions, and collecting rational number like terms.

title: Absolute value to find distance challenge
description: Solve conceptually challenging absolute value problems. In order to succeed at these problems, you'll need to remember that the absolute value of the difference of two numbers is the distance between those numbers.

title: Topic A: Lessons 1-3: Piecewise, quadratic, and exponential functions
Topic B: Solve problems using expressions, equations, and inequalities
description:
Topic B includes lessons 7-15 and covers understanding equations, using if-then moves in solving equations, angle problems and solving equations, properties of inequalities, inequalities, solving inequalities, and graphing solutions to inequalities.

(Currently, we do not have content for Lesson 9.)

title: Topic B: Percent problems including more than one whole
description:
Topic B includes lessons 7-11 and covers markup and markdown problems, percent error problems, problem solving when the percent changes, simple interest, and tax, commissions, fees, and other real-world percent problems.

(Currently, we do not have content for Lessons 8 and 9.)

title: Topic B: Multiplication and division of integers and rational numbers
description: Topic B includes lessons 10-16 and covers understanding multiplication of integers, develop rules for multiplying signed numbers, division of integers, converting between fractions and decimals using equivalent fractions, converting rational numbers to decimals using long division, multiplication and division of rational numbers, and applying the properties of operations to multiply and divide rational numbers.

title: Topic A: Exponential notation and properties of integer exponents
description: Topic A includes lessons 1-6 and covers exponential notation, multiplication and division of numbers in exponential form, numbers in exponential form raised to a power, numbers raised to the zeroth power, negative exponents and the laws of exponents, and proofs of laws of exponents.

title: Topic C: Scale drawings
description:
Topic C includes lessons 12-15 and covers the scale factor as a percent for a scale drawing, changing scales, computing actual lengths from a scale drawing, and solving area problems using scale drawings.

(Currently, we do not have content for Lesson 12.)

title: Topic C: Use equations and inequalities to solve geometry problems
description:
Topic C includes lessons 16-26 and covers the most famous ratio of all, the area of a circle, more problems on area and circumference, unknown area problems on the coordinate plane, composite area problems, surface area, the volume of a right prism, and volume and surface area.

(Currently, we do not have content for Lesson 18.)

title: Topic D: Population, mixture, and counting problems involving percents
description: Topic D includes lessons 16-18 and covers population problems, mixture problems, and counting problems.

title: Module 4, Topic D: No content yet
Topic B: Magnitude and scientific notation
description:
Topic B includes lessons 7-13 and covers magnitude, estimating quantities, scientific notation, operations with numbers in scientific notation, efficacy of scientific notation, choice of unit, and comparison of numbers written in scientific notation and interpreting scientific notation using technology.

(Currently, we do not have content for Lesson 7.)

title: Topic A: Calculating and interpreting probabilities
description:
Topic A includes lessons 1-7 and covers chance experiments, estimating probabilities by collecting data, chance experiments with equally likely outcomes, calculating probabilities for chance experiments with equally likely outcomes, chance experiments with outcomes that are not equally likely, using tree diagrams to represent a sample space and to calculate probabilities, and calculating probabilities of compound events.

(Currently, we do not have content for Lesson 2.)

title: Simplifying complex fractions
description: Learn how to take complex looking fractions and make them much, much simpler.

title: Simplify complex fractions
description: Practice simplifying complex fractions.

title: Dividing by zero
description: Practice identifying when a quotient is undefined because of division by zero.

title: Topic C: The Pythagorean theorem
description: Topic C includes lessons 13-14 and covers proof of the Pythagorean theorem and the converse of the Pythagorean theorem.

title: Topic C: Lesson 23: Solution sets to simultaneous equations
Topic D: Creating equations to solve problems
Topic C: Applying operations with rational numbers to expressions and equations
description:
Topic C includes lessons 17-23 and covers comparing tape diagram solutions to algebraic solutions, writing, evaluating, and finding equivalent expressions with rational numbers, investmentsperforming operations with rational numbers, if-then moves with integer number cards, and solving equations using algebra.

(Currently, we do not have content for Lessons 17 and 22.)

title: Topic B: Estimating probabilities
description:
Topic B includes lessons 8-12 and covers the difference between theoretical probabilities and estimated probabilities, comparing estimated probabilities to probabilities predicted by a model, conducting a simulation to estimate the probability of an event, and applying probability to make informed decisions.

(Currently, we do not have content for Lesson 11.)

title: Topic A: Unknown angles
description: Topic A includes lessons 1-4 and covers complementary and supplementary angles and solving for unknown angles using equations.

title: Topic A: Definitions and properties of the basic rigid motions
description:
Topic A includes lessons 1-6 and covers definition of translation and three basic properties, translating lines, definition of reflection and basic properties, definition of rotation and basic properties, and rotations of 180 degrees.

(Currently, we do not have content for Lesson 1.)

title: Introduction to geometric transformations
description: how are virtual sets built in the computer?

title: Topic C: Random sampling and estimating population characteristics
description:
Topic C includes lessons 13-20 and covers populations, samples, and generalizing from a sample to a population, selecting a sample, random sampling, methods for selecting a random sample, sampling variability, sampling variability and the effect of sample size, understanding variability when estimating a population proportion, and estimating a population proportion.

(Currently, we do not have content for Lessons 19 and 20.)

title: Topic D: Comparing populations
description: Topic D includes lessons 21-23 and covers why worry about sampling variability? and using sample data to compare the means of two or more populations.

title: Topic A: Dilation
description:
Topic A includes lessons 1-7 and covers what lies behind same shape?, properties of dilations, examples of dilations, fundamental theorem of similarity (FTS), first consequences of FTS, and dilations on the coordinate plane.

(Currently, we do not have content for Lessons 4 and 5.)

title: Topic A: Writing and solving linear equations
description:
Topic A includes lessons 1-9 and covers writing equations using symbols, linear and nonlinear expressions in , linear equations in , solving a linear equation, writing and solving linear equations, solutions of a linear equation, classification of solutions, linear equations in disguise, and an application of linear equations.

(Currently, we do not have content for Lessons 2 and 5.)

title: Topic B: Constructing triangles
description:
Topic B includes lessons 5-15 and covers identical triangles, drawing geometric shapes, drawing parallelograms, drawing triangles, conditions for a unique trianglethree sides and two sides and the included angle, conditions for a unique triangletwo angles and a given side, conditions on measurements that determine a triangle, unique trianglestwo sides and a non-included angle, checking for identical triangles, and using unique triangles to solve real-world and mathematical problems.

(Currently, we do not have content for Lessons 7 and 15.)

title: Constructing triangles
description: Practice constructing triangles.

title: Ordering triangle sides and angles example
description: Sal first solves a problem where he orders the sides of a triangle given the angles, then solves a problem where he orders the angles of a triangle given the sides.

title: Topic B: Similar figures
description: Topic B includes lessons 8-12 and covers similarity, basic properties of similarity, informal proof of AA criterion for similarity, more about similar triangles, and modeling using similarity.

title: Ordering triangle sides and angles
description: Apply the property that the longest side of a triangle is opposite the largest angle to solve a few problems.

title: Topic C: Slope and equations of lines
description: Topic C includes lessons 15-23 and covers the slope of a non-vertical line, the computation of the slope of a non-vertical line, the line joining two distinct points of the graph  =  +  has Slope , there Is only one line passing through a given point with a given slope, the graph of a linear equation in two variables is a line, every line is a graph of a linear equation, some facts about graphs of linear equations in two variables, constant rates revisited, and the defining equation of a line.

title: Topic A: Functions
description: Topic A includes lessons 1-8 and covers the concept of a function, formal definition of a function, linear functions and proportionality, more examples of functions, graphs of functions and equations, graphs of linear functions and rate of change, comparing linear functions and graphs, and graphs of simple nonlinear functions.

title: Topic D: The Pythagorean theorem
description: Topic D includes lessons 15-16 and covers informal proof of the Pythagorean theorem and applications of the Pythagorean theorem.

title: Module 2, Topic D: No content yet
Topic A: Linear functions
description: Topic A includes lessons 1-5 and covers modeling linear relationships, interpreting rate of change and initial value, representations of a line, and increasing and decreasing functions.

title: Topic B: Volume
description:
Topic B includes lessons 9-11 and covers examples of functions from geometry, volumes of familiar solidscones and cylinders, and volume of a sphere.

(Currently, we do not have content for Lesson 9.)

title: Topic B: Bivariate numerical data
description: Topic B includes lessons 6-9 and covers scatter plots, patterns in scatter plots, informally fitting a line, and determining the equation of a line fit to data.

title: Topic B: Lesson 7: Solve for unknown anglestransversals
Topic B: Lessons 9-11: Unknown angle proofs
Topic A: Lesson 5: The zero product property
Topic D: Using functions and graphs to solve problems

Triangle medians and centroids (2D proof)
description: Showing that the centroid is 2/3 of the way along a median

title: Topic E: Lessons 32-33: Laws of sines and cosines
Topic D: Equations for circles and their tangents
Topic D: Systems of linear equations and their solutions
description: Topic D includes lessons 24-30 and covers introduction to simultaneous equations, geometric interpretation of the solutions of a linear system, characterization of parallel lines, nature of solutions of a system of linear equations, another computational method of solving a linear system, word problems, and conversion between celsius and fahrenheit.

title: Topic A: Lesson 1: Dot plots and histograms
description: It's not easy to see patterns or relationships when all you have are large lists of numbers. We use dot plots, histograms, and stem and leaf plots to display quantitative data so it is easier to understand what the data is saying.

title: Systems of equations with elimination: 3t+4g=6 & -6t+g=6
description: Sal solves the system of equations 3t + 4g = 6 and -6t + g = 6 using elimination.

title: Systems of equations with elimination
description: Walk through examples of solving systems of equations with elimination.

title: Topic A: Lesson 1: Box plots and shape
description: Box and whisker plots show us the shape, center, spread, and even more features about a set of data. We'll learn how to construct box and whisker plots (often called box plots), and we'll also look at how to read and interpret box plots.

title: Systems of equations with elimination: x+2y=6 & 4x-2y=14
description: Learn to use elimination to solve the system of equations x + 2y = 6 and 4x - 2y = 14.

title: Systems of equations with elimination: -3y+4x=11 & y+2x=13
description: Sal solves the system of equations -3y + 4x = 11 and y + 2x = 13 using elimination.

title: Systems of equations with elimination: 2x-y=14 & -6x+3y=-42
description: Sal solves the system of equations 2x - y = 14 and -6x + 3y = -42 using elimination.

title: Systems of equations with elimination: 4x-2y=5 & 2x-y=2.5
description: Sal solves the system of equations 4x - 2y = 5 and 2x - y = 2.5 using elimination.

title: Topic C: Linear and nonlinear models
description: Topic C includes lessons 10-12 and covers linear models, using linear models in a data context, and nonlinear models in a data context (Optional).

title: Systems of equations with elimination: 6x-6y=-24 & -5x-5y=-60
description: Sal solves the system of equations 6x - 6y = -24 and -5x - 5y = -60 using elimination.

title: Topic A: Lesson 2: Describing the center of a distribution
description: We use measures of center like mean and median to summarize an entire set of data with just one number. Let's look at how to calculate mean and median given raw data or a data display.

title: Topic A: Lessons 1-2: Factoring binomials intro
Topic A: Lessons 3-4: Factoring by grouping
Topic B: Lessons 14-15: The quadratic formula
Topic A: Lesson 3: Estimating centers and interpreting the mean as a balance point
description: Once you know the basics of how to calculate the mean and median, you can start to think deeper about more advanced concepts. This tutorial covers how to find the mean and median from a data display, how new data points impact the mean and median, and how to find missing values given a mean.

title: Systems of equations with elimination: Sum/difference of numbers
description: Sal finds two numbers that sum to 70 and have a difference of 24.

title: Topic D: Bivariate categorical data
description: Topic D includes lessons 13-14 and covers summarizing bivariate categorical data in a two-way table and association between categorical variables.

title: Systems of equations with substitution: shelves
description: Sal solves a system of equations to figure out how long a couple of different shelves will be.

title: Systems of equations number of solutions: y=3x+1 & 2y+4=6x
description: Sal graphs a system of equations to find the number of solutions it has.

title: Topic B: Lessons 5-6: Standard deviation and variability
description: If our data came from a sample, and we want to use it to represent its larger population, we need to slightly modify our formulas for variance and standard deviation. Let's look at how to calculate variance and standard deviation based on sample data.

title: Topic A: Square and cube roots
description: Topic A includes lessons 1-5 and covers the Pythagorean theorem, square roots, existence and uniqueness of square roots and cube roots, simplifying square roots (Optional), and solving equations with radicals.

title: Forming systems of equations with different numbers of solutions
description: Sal write an equation that along with the equation 4x + 5y = 2 forms a system of equations with infinitely many solutions.

title: Comparing Celsius and Fahrenheit temperature scales
description: Comparing Celsius and Fahrenheit temperature scales

title: Topic B: Lesson 7: Measuring variability for skewed distributions (interquartile range)
Converting Fahrenheit to Celsius
description: Converting Fahrenheit to Celsius

title: Topic B: Decimal expansions of numbers
description:
Topic B includes lessons 6-14 and covers finite and infinite decimals, infinite decimals, the long division algorithm, decimal expansions of fractions, converting repeating decimals to fractions, the decimal expansion of some irrational numbers, comparing irrational numbers, and decimal expansion of pi.

(Currently, we do not have content for Lesson 8 and 14.)

title: Topic D: Lessons 12-13: Relationships between two numerical variables
Topic C: The Pythagorean theorem
description: Topic A includes lessons 15-18 and covers Pythagorean theorem, converse of the Pythagorean theorem, distance on the coordinate plane, and applications of the Pythagorean theorem.

title: Topic D: Lesson 14: Modeling relationships with a line
Module 7, Topic D: No content yet
Dividing triangles with medians
description: Showing that the three medians of a triangle divide it into six smaller triangles of equal area. Brief discussion of the centroid as well

title: Exploring medial triangles
description: What a medial triangle is and its properties

title: Centroid & median proof
description: Showing that the centroid divides each median into segments with a 2:1 ratio (or that the centroid is 2/3 along the median)

title: Median, centroid example
description: Example involving properties of medians

title: Distance between point & line
description: The distance from a point to a line is the shortest distance between the point and any point on the line. This can be done with a variety of tools like slope-intercept form and the Pythagorean Theorem.

title: Distance between point & line
description: Find the distance between a point and a line. Watch out, some lines of the lines are perfectly horizontal or vertical.

title: Topic A: Lessons 2-4: Two-way tables, conditional probability, and independence
Logarithmic equations: variable in the argument
description: Sal solves the equation log(x)+log(3)=2log(4)-log(2).

title: Logarithmic equations: variable in the base
description: Sal solves the equation 4=log_b(81).

title: Topic B: Lessons 14-17: Multiplying and dividing complex numbers in polar form
Intro to linear systems with 3 variables
description: Sal discusses how we approach solving systems of three variables algebraically, and how we visualize it graphically.

title: Solving linear systems with 3 variables
description: Sal solves a system of three variables using elimination.

title: Area of a circle
description: This was made for a hackathon back in 2014!

title: Square-root equations
description: Learn how to solve equations with square-root expressions in them. For example, solve (2x-5)=(7-3x).

title: Topic B & C: Foundations
description: Foundational material to help you prepare for Eureka Math/EngageNY 8th Grade, Module 6 Topics B and C

title: Maximum and minimum points
description: Learn about maximum and minimum points of functions.

title: Synthetic division of polynomials
description: Learn how to divide polynomials using long division.

title: Graphs of polynomials
description: Combine your knowledge about the zeros and the end behavior of a polynomial in order to sketch its graph.

title: Comparing multi-digit numbers
description: Compare whole numbers with at least 3 digits.

title: Subtraction within 100
description: Learn to subtract two-digit numbers like 47 and 39.

title: Multi-digit multiplication
description: Learn to multiply multi-digit whole numbers with and without regrouping.

title: Decimals on the number line
description: See how decimals can be placed on the number line, just like fractions and whole numbers can.

title: Topic C: Foundations
description: Foundational material to help you prepare for Eureka Math/EngageNY 8th Grade, Module 7 Topic C

title: Linear equations with variables on both sides
description: Learn how to solve linear equations that have the variable on both sides of the equation. For example, solve 2x+5=6x-3.

title: Rate conversion
description: Practice solving word problems that involve the conversion between different units for the same quantity. For example, a rate problem where some rates are in km/h and some are in m/s.

title: Extraneous solutions of radical equations
description: Learn about the conditions for obtaining extraneous solutions while solving radical equations.

title: Linear equations with parentheses
description: Learn how to solve linear equations with parentheses using the distributive property. For example, solve -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6).

title: Topic D: Foundations
description: Foundational material to help you prepare for Eureka Math/EngageNY 8th Grade, Module 7 Topic D

title: Appropriate units
description: Learn how to work with units that are arithmetic combinations of more simple units. For example, velocity units are quotients of distance units over time units, which corresponds to the formula v=d/t.

title: Cube-root equations
description: Learn how to solve equations with cube-root expressions in them. For example, solve (2-6x)=x+3.

title: Analyzing the number of solutions to linear equations
description: Linear equations can either have a single solution, infinite solutions, or no solutions. Learn how to determine the number of solutions to a given equation, and how to create equations with a desired number of solutions.

title: Domain of radical functions
description: Learn how the domain of radical functions is determined.

title: Graphs of radical functions
description: Learn how the graphs of radical functions look, and how we can reason about them using function transformations (i.e. shifts, stretches, etc.).

title: Word problems with multiple units
description: Practice solving word problems that involve a variety of units.

title: Linear equations with unknown coefficients
description: An equation like ax+3x=bx+5 can still be solved for x even though some of the coefficients are variables.

title: Multi-step inequalities
description: Solve any possible linear inequality in one variable. For example, solve -3x-7<x+9.

title: Two-variable linear equations intro
description: Understand what a solution to an equation really means. Practice plugging in values for variables to see whether or not an equation is true.

title: Evaluating functions
description: Learn how to find the value of a function for a given input value.

title: Interpreting linear functions and equations
description: Solve word problems where you need to answer a question about a real-world relationship based on its mathematical model.

title: Compound inequalities
description: Learn how to solve compound inequalities. For example, solve 2x+1>3 AND -x-5<4.

title: x-intercepts and y-intercepts
description: Learn about intercepts and practice finding them from graphs, tables, and equations.

title: Inputs and outputs of a function
description: Extend your understanding of the relationship between the inputs of a function and the outputs of that function.

title: Point-slope form
description: (y-b)=m(x-a)

title: Comparing linear functions
description: Compare features of linear functions, such as slope and intercepts, where the functions are given in different formstables, graphs, or formulas.

title: Systems of equations overview
description: This video series covers everything you need to know about systems of equations, through stories about trolls, kings, and cupcakes!

title: Functions and equations
description: Understand the subtle differences and similarities between functions and equations. In this exercise, we will see how an equation can be turned into a function.

title: Interpreting function notation
description: Solve some word problems by interpreting expressions of modeling functions.

title: Constructing linear models for real-world relationships
description: Learn how to represent real-world relationships (that are described verbally) with linear graphs, equations, or functions.

title: Introduction to systems of equations
description: Learn what "systems of equations" are, what counts as a solution to such a system, and how we can use graphs to solve them.

title: Introduction to the domain and range of a function
description: Learn what the domain and the range of a function are. Practice finding the domain and the range of a function given its graph.

title: Horizontal & vertical lines
description: You know what horizontal and vertical lines are, but how do their equations look? And what is their slope? Learn all about it in this tutorial.

title: Linear models word problems
description: Solve general word problems about real-world relationships that can be modeled by linear equations or functions.

title: Intro to slope-intercept form
description: Make an introduction with the most common form of linear equations, slope-intercept form! For example, y=3x+5 is a linear equation in slope-intercept form.

title: Determining the domain of a function
description: Determine the domains of functions according to various considerations.

title: Equivalent systems of equations and the elimination method
description: Learn about the elimination method, which is a way manipulate systems of equations in order to solve them algebraically. This is actually very similar to the way we manipulate single equations in order to solve them!

title: Checking solutions of two-variable inequalities
description: Learn how to check possible solutions of two-variable linear inequalities. For example, is (2, 0) a solution to y>x+1? In this tutorial, we also check solutions to systems of inequalities.

title: Graphing slope-intercept equations
description: Learn how to graph linear equations that are given in slope-intercept form. For example, graph y=2x+3.

title: Recognizing functions
description: Learn how to distinguish between two-variable relationships that are functions and two-variable relationships that aren't functions.

title: Writing slope-intercept equations
description: Learn how to write the equation of a line (in slope-intercept form) when given the graph of the equation or two points on the line. For example, write the equation of the line that passes through the points (0,1) and (5,4).

title: Graphing two-variable inequalities
description: Learn how to graph two-variables linear inequalities and systems of two-variable linear inequalities.

title: Solving systems of equations with substitution
description: Learn about the substitution method, which is another way to manipulate systems of equations in order to solve them.

title: Standard form
description: ax+by=c

title: Modeling with linear inequalities
description: Learn how to construct linear inequalities and systems of inequalities given a real-life context. Learn how to interpret such inequalities in terms of a real-life context, either algebraically or graphically.

title: Manipulating expressions with unknown variables
description: Learn how to rewrite expressions with variables whose values are unknown, by using another information about those variables. For example, given that a+b=0, express a*b in terms of b alone.

title: Intervals where a function is positive, negative, increasing, or decreasing
description: Learn about features of functions that have distinct graphical representations: intervals where the function is always positive or always negative, and intervals where the function is always increasing or always decreasing.

title: Number of solutions to systems of equations
description: Learn about the possible number of solutions of systems of linear equations. Spoiler: There can be a single solution, zero solutions, or infinite solutions. These different cases define the distinctions between "consistent" and "inconsistent" systems, and between "dependent" and "independent" systems.

title: Interpreting features of graphs
description: Interpret the graphs of functions in terms of the contexts that are modeled by the functions.

title: Summary: Forms of two-variable linear equations
description: Take an overview of the three main forms of linear equations: slope-intercept, point-slope, and standard. Learn which form is most appropriate for different uses.

title: Average rate of change
description: Learn what's the average rate of change of a function and how to find it over given intervals.

title: Solving any system of linear equations
description: Use everything you learned so far in order to solve any kind of system of equations!

title: Creating and interpreting scatterplots
description: Do people who eat more vegetables tend to be happier? Is crime getting better or worse over time? In this tutorial we'll make scatterplots to see if there is a correlation between two variables.

title: Systems of equations word problems
description: Now that we are able to solve any kind of system we are given, it's time to use that knowledge to solve some word problems.

title: Average rate of change word problems
description: Solve word problems that concern the average rate of change of a functional relationship.

title: Displays of distributions
description: A picture says a thousand words. A well-made data display can show data in a way that everyone understands. In this tutorial we'll learn how to construct and describe some common displays of data.

title: Estimating with trend lines
description: If we know how big a persons feet are, can we predict their height? In this tutorial, we'll fit a line to the pattern we see and use it to make predictions.

title: Two-way frequency tables
description: Frequency tables show us how many times something happened. This tutorial covers how to read and interpret two-way frequency tables.

title: Adding & subtracting polynomials: two variables
description: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial that involve two variables. For example, x^3 + xy + 3y - (x^3 + 6xy + 2y^2).

title: Manipulating formulas
description: Learn how to solve problems that involve multi-variable formulas.

title: Equation with two rational expressions (old example)
description: Sal solves the equation 4/(p-1)=5/(p+3).

title: Summarizing center of distributions (central tendency)
description: How long does a typical person spend on a phone each week? Is it different for younger people? In this tutorial we'll use measures of center like mean and median to summarize and compare sets of data.

title: Two-way relative frequency tables
description: Relative frequency tables show us what percent of the time something happened. This tutorial covers how to construct, read, and and interpret two-way relative frequency tables.

title: Introduction to arithmetic sequences
description: Learn about arithmetic sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common difference. Evaluate arithmetic sequences.

title: Exponent properties review
description: Practice using the exponent properties to rewrite powers, where the exponent is an integer that can either be positive or negative.

title: Multiplying & dividing powers (integer exponents)
description: For any base a and any integer exponents n and m, aa=a. For any nonzero base, a/a=a. These are worked examples for using these properties with integer exponents.

title: Box and whisker plots
description: Whether we're looking at scientific data or stock price charts, box-and-whisker plots can show up in life. This tutorial covers what they are, how to read them and how to construct them.

title: Exponential vs. linear growth
description: Learn about exponential growth and decay, and specifically how it always grows (or diminishes) by equal factors.

title: Constructing arithmetic sequences
description: Learn how to find the explicit or recursive formula of an arithmetic sequence.

title: Radicals
description: Radicals (also known as roots) are a generalization of square roots. They are the inverse operation of any power. For example, the 5th root of 32 is 2, because 2=32.

title: Comparing distributions
description: Do people live longer in different parts of the world? In this tutorial well compare the center and spread of distributions to see what conclusions we can make.

title: Exponential expressions
description: Learn how to construct exponential functions to model real-world situations.

title: Rational exponents intro
description: Learn the definition for raising a number by a fractional exponent, like 8^.

title: Introduction to geometric sequences
description: Learn about geometric sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common ratio. Evaluate geometric sequences.

title: Introduction to rigid transformations
description: The three rigid transformations are translations, rotations, and reflections. Get to know them and gain some experience in performing them on different figures.

title: Graphs of exponential growth
description: Learn how an exponential function behaves as the value of its input increases to positive infinity or decreases to negative infinity. Learn how to graph basic exponential functions.

title: Properties of exponents (rational exponents)
description: In this tutorial you will rewrite variable expressions with rational exponents using the properties of exponents.

title: Density
description: Use your knowledge of surface area and volume to solve problems involving density.

title: Graphs of logarithmic functions
description: Learn about the graphs of logarithmic functions, and how they relate to graphs of exponential functions.

title: Numbers 0 to 120
description: Learn the numbers from 0 to 120.

title: Exponential vs. linear growth over time
description: Learn how to distinguish between linear and exponential growth, and learn the differences between the end behavior of polynomial and exponential functions.

title: Translations
description: Learn how to find the translation that maps a given figure to another, and how to manually draw the image of a translation.

title: Constructing geometric sequences
description: Learn how to find the explicit or recursive formula of a geometric sequence.

title: Exponential decay
description: Learn how to construct exponential functions and then analyze them to model and solve real-world problems.

title: Advanced exponent & radical evaluation
description: Evaluate elaborate expressions that contain radicals and fractional exponents.

title: Modeling with sequences
description: Now that we've mastered arithmetic and geometric sequences, let's see how they can help us solve real-world word problems. In this tutorial you will find the formula for a sequence that models a real-world relationship.

title: Exponential functions from tables & graphs
description: Learn how to analyze the formulas of basic exponential functions in order to find their common ratio, initial value, and other parameters.

title: General sequences
description: Arithmetic and geometric sequences are very useful, but they are definitely not the only kinds of sequences out there. Let's zoom out and consider some other kinds of sequences.

title: Simplifying square roots
description: We know how to evaluate square roots of perfect squares. For example, 16=4. What about the other square roots? It's harder to give an exact number, but we can simplify them so we have a better understanding of their value. For example, 32=42. Learn more about it in this tutorial.

title: Rotations
description: Learn how to find the rotation that maps a given figure to another, and how to manually draw the image of a rotation.

title: Transformations & congruence
description: Two figures are congruent if you can go from one to another through some combination of translations, reflections and rotations.  In this tutorial, we'll really internalize this by working through the actual transformations.

title: Distance and midpoints
description: Find the distance between two points or the midpoint of two points.

title: Simplifying radicals (higher-index roots)
description: Just like we can simplify square roots, we can simplify other radicals. This tutorial covers the simplification of higher-index roots. For example, 48=23.

title: Triangle congruence
description: Learn how the definition of congruence using rigid transformations can be simplified to simple criteria when studying congruent triangles.

title: Reflections
description: Learn how to find the reflection that maps a given figure to another, and how to manually draw the image of a reflection.

title: Graphs of absolute value functions
description: Learn how to graph absolute value functions like f(x)=|x+2|-8.

title: Theorems concerning triangle properties
description: Now that we know how to show that two triangles are congruent, let's put that to use by proving some theorems about triangles.

title: Dividing line segments
description: Think about ratios of lengths of segments between points.

title: Working with triangles
description: Learn how to solve different geometric problems using triangle congruence.

title: Rigid transformations overview
description: After studying each rigid transformation in separate, it's time to take a broader look at those transformations: which properties are preserved under which kind of transformation, and how do we map shapes using sequences of rigid transformations?

title: Problem solving with distance on the coordinate plane
description: Use what you know about distance to solve problems on the coordinate plan like finding the perimeter of a shape or determining if a point is on a circle.

title: Dilations
description:
In addition to the three rigid transformation, there are the dilations, which expand or shrink figures while keeping the same proportions. These are extremely important in the subject of Similarity!

Gain experience by performing dilation, learn how to find the dilation that maps a given figure to another, and learn how to manually draw the image of a dilation.

title: Piecewise functions
description: We are used to functions that have the same rule for all inputs. For example, f(x)=x outputs the square of every input. Piecewise functions have different output rules, depending on the inputs. For example, we can define function g to output x for all positive values of x and x for all negative values of x, so g(2)=4 and g(-2)=-8.

title: Theorems concerning quadrilateral properties
description: Triangle congruence is not only useful when working with triangles, it's also useful with any other kind of polygon! Prove a few theorems about the properties of parallelograms using triangle congruence.

title: Parallel & perpendicular lines on the coordinate plane
description: You probably know what parallel and perpendicular lines are. In this tutorial, you will learn how these relationships are expressed on the coordinate plane (spoiler: parallel lines have the same slope, and the product of the slopes of perpendicular lines is always -1).

title: Proofs of general theorems that use triangle congruence
description: Gain even more experience with using triangle congruence in proofs.

title: Equations of parallel & perpendicular lines
description: Learn all about equations of parallel and perpendicular

title: Properties & definitions of transformations
description: Let's continue our deep voyage through the world of transformations! Use your knowledge about the precise descriptions of the rigid transformations and their properties in various situations.

title: Constructing bisectors of lines & angles
description: With just a compass and a straightedge  (or virtual versions of them), you'll be amazed by how many geometric shapes you can construct perfectly.  This tutorial gets you started with the building block of how to bisect angle and lines (and how to construct perpendicular bisectors of lines).

title: Intro to polynomials
description: Learn about polynomial expressions: What are they? How are they constructed? What can we do with them?

title: Symmetry
description: Learn about different kinds of symmetries of two-dimensional shapes, and analyze various shapes according to their symmetries.

title: Adding & subtracting polynomials
description: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial expressions with one variable.

title: Introduction to factorization
description: Learn what factorization is all about, and warm-up by factoring some monomials.

title: Coordinate plane proofs
description: Prove properties of shapes by putting them on the coordinate plane and then using distances, midpoints, and slopes.

title: Factoring monomials
description: Learn how to write a monomial as a factor of two other monomials. For example, write 12x^3 as (4x)(3x^2).

title: Irrational numbers
description: Learn what irrational numbers are. Also learn how to classify numbers as whole, integer, rational, and irrational.

title: Parabolas intro
description: Learn what parabolas are and about their main features: their general shape, vertex, and axis of symmetry.

title: 2D vs. 3D objects
description: Visualize the relation between two-dimensional and three-dimensional objects.

title: Quadratic factored form
description: The factored form of a quadratic function is an expression that is, well, factored! Like f(x)=(2x+1)(x-3). Learn how to analyze functions given in this form to find their zeros, their vertex, and their graph.

title: Sums & products of rational/irrational numbers
description: Determine whether various combinations of rational and irrational numbers are rational or irrational themselves.

title: Factoring polynomials by taking common factors
description: Learn how to take a common monomial factor out of a polynomial expression. For example, write 2x^3+6x^2+8x as (2x)(x^2+3x+4).

title: Proofs concerning irrational numbers
description: Learn some proofs about the existence of irrational numbers.

title: Solving quadratics by taking square roots
description: In this tutorial you will learn about the most basic way of solving quadratic equations.

title: Multiplying monomials
description: As an intro to more elaborate polynomial multiplication, learn how to multiply monomials (which are polynomials with a single term). For example, multiply 2x and 5x.

title: Evaluating expressions with unknown variables
description: Learn how to evaluate expressions with variables whose values are unknown, by using another information about those variables. For example, given that a+b=3, evaluate 4a+4b.

title: What are the imaginary numbers?
description: Learn about the imaginary unit i (which is the square root of -1) and about imaginary numbers like 3i (which is the square root of -9).

title: Factoring quadratics intro
description: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient of 1. For example, factor x+3x+2 as (x+1)(x+2).

title: Multiplying monomials by polynomials
description: Learn how to multiply a polynomial expression by a monomial expression. Monomials are just polynomials with a single term!

title: Quadratic vertex form
description: The vertex form of a quadratic function shows the coordinates of the parabola's vertex. For example, the vertex of g(x)=(x-1)+2 is at (1,2). Learn how to analyze functions given in this form to find their zeros, their vertex, and their graph.

title: What are the complex numbers?
description: Learn about complex numbers (spoiler: they are numbers that consist of both real and imaginary parts).

title: Factoring quadratics by grouping
description: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient other than 1. For example, factor 2x+7x+3 as (2x+1)(x+3).

title: Solving quadratics by factoring
description: In this tutorial, you'll learn some pretty elaborate ways of solving quadratic equations, by harnessing the mighty strength of algebra.

title: Multiplying binomials
description: Learn how to multiply two binomials together. For example, (3x - 7) * (10x + 2).

title: The complex plane
description: Learn how we can visualize complex numbers in a plane. This can be seen as an expansion of the 1-dimensional real number line into a 2-dimensional plane!

title: Constructing exponential models according to rate of change
description: Learn how to find the modeling function of an exponential real world context, according to the description of its rate of change.

title: Sectors
description: Learn how to find the area of a sector.

title: Multiplying & dividing rational expressions
description: Learn how to multiply and divide rational expressions. You will be surprised to see how similar it is to multiplying and dividing fractions!

title: Factoring polynomials with quadratic forms
description: Learn how to factor quadratic polynomials of the form ax^2+bx+c as the product of two linear binomials. For example, write x^2+3x-10 as (x+5)(x-2). Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate polynomials that aren't necessarily quadratic. For example, write x^4-4x^2-12 as (x^2+2)(x^2-6).

title: Adding & subtracting complex numbers
description: Learn how to add or subtract complex numbers. For example, write (2+3i)-(1+2i) as (1+i).

title: Multiplying binomials by polynomials
description: Learn how to multiply a polynomial expression by a binomial expression.

title: Factoring quadratics: Difference of squares
description: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "difference of squares" form. For example, write x-16 as (x+4)(x-4). Learn how to identify this form in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x-49 as (2x+7)(2x-7).

title: Completing the square
description: You're already familiar with factoring quadratics, but have begun to realize that it only is useful in certain cases.  Well, this tutorial will introduce you to something far more powerful and general.  Even better, it is the bridge to understanding and proving the famous quadratic formula.

title: Multiplying complex numbers
description: Learn how to multiply complex numbers using the fact that i^2=-1 and the distributive property. For example, multiply (1+i) by (2+3i).

title: Special products of binomials
description: Learn about the special types of products of binomials: perfect squares and the difference of two squares. These will be very helpful once you tackle more advanced expressions in Algebra.

title: Equivalent forms of exponential expressions
description: Learn how to manipulate exponential expressions in different ways. For example, rewrite 8^x as 2^(3x).

title: Factoring quadratics: Perfect squares
description: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "perfect square" form. For example, write x+6x+9 as (x+3). Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x+28x+49 as (2x+7).

title: The quadratic formula
description: Learn how to solve any quadratic equation with the most general tool of all, the quadratic formula!

title: Exponential equations: properties of exponents
description: Learn how to solve advanced exponential equations by manipulating the expressions in the equations using the properties of exponents. For example, solve 2^(x+1)=8^x by rewriting 8^x as 2^(3x) and then equating x+1=3x.

title: Polynomials word problems
description: See a few examples of how we can represent real-world situations with polynomials.

title: Interpreting the rate of change of exponential models
description: Learn how to analyze exponential modeling functions in order to find their rate of change.

title: Long division of polynomials
description: Learn how to divide two polynomials using long division.

title: Strategy in factoring quadratics
description: There are a lot of methods to factor quadratics, which apply on different occasions and conditions. Now that we know all of them, let's think strategically about which of them is useful for a given quadratic expression we want to factor.

title: Factoring polynomials with special product forms
description: Factor polynomials of various degrees using factorization methods that are based on the special product forms "difference of squares" and "perfect squares." For example, factor 25x-30x+9 as (5x-3).

title: Quadratic standard form
description: In this tutorial, we will learn how to graph quadratic functions given in different forms.

title: Properties of tangents
description: Explore, prove, and apply properties of circles that involve tangents.

title: Practice dividing polynomials with remainders
description: After learning about the different methods in which we can find the quotient and the remainder of two polynomials, gain some practice with actually performing polynomial division yourself.

title: Advanced interpretation of exponential models
description: Learn how to interpret an exponential modeling function by first manipulating it according to your needs. For example, rewrite 5^(2x+1) as 5*25^x to find that the unit growth factor is 25.

title: Polynomial Remainder Theorem
description: The polynomial remainder theorem allows us to easily determine whether a linear expression is a factor of a given polynomial. Learn exactly what the theorem means, practice using it, and learn about its proof.

title: Features & forms of quadratic functions
description: Learn about the features of quadratic functions, and how to find them given the formula of the function. Also learn about the different forms of quadratic functions: standard, vertex, and factored.

title: Distinguishing between linear and exponential growth
description: Learn how to analyze real-world quantitative relationships given as tables of values to determine whether they represent linear growth or exponential growth.

title: Modeling with one-variable equations & inequalities
description: Learn how to determine the appropriate *type* of modeling equation (or inequality) according to the description of a real-world context.

title: Definitions of similarity
description: In this tutorial, you will learn how we determine whether two figures are similar.

title: Introduction to triangle similarity
description: In this tutorial, we will use what we learned about similarity of polygons in the specific case of triangles. We will come up with specific conditions for triangles to be similar, and use them to determine whether two triangles are similar.

title: Pythagorean theorem
description:
Named after the Greek philosopher who lived nearly 2600 years ago, the Pythagorean theorem is as good as math theorems get (Pythagoras also started a religious movement).  It's simple.  It's beautiful.  It's powerful.

In this tutorial, we will cover what it is and how it can be used.  We have another tutorial that gives you as many proofs of it as you might need.

title: Transforming parabolas
description: Learn how function transformations affect the graphs of quadratic functions.

title: Solid geometry intro
description: Tired of perimeter and area and now want to measure 3-D space-take-upness.  Well you've found the right tutorial.  Enjoy!

title: Solving similar triangles
description: Learn how to find missing measures of triangles using the fact that they are similar to other triangles.

title: Pythagorean theorem proofs
description: The Pythagorean theorem is one of the most famous ideas in all of mathematics.  This tutorial proves it.  Then proves it again... and again... and again.  More than just satisfying any skepticism of whether the Pythagorean theorem is really true (only one proof would be sufficient for that), it will hopefully open your mind to new and beautiful ways to prove something very powerful.

title: Circle basics
description: Make sure you're familiar with notation and key terms like radius, diameter, circumference, pi, tangent, secant, and major/minor arcs before you dive into the rest of the circles content.

title: Angle bisector theorem
description: Learn about the angle bisector theorem, which makes a clever use of triangle similarity in order to find a special proportion that holds for angle bisectors of triangles.

title: Special right triangles
description: We hate to pick favorites, but there really are certain right triangles that are more special than others.  In this tutorial, we pick them out, show why they're special, and prove it!  These include 30-60-90 and 45-45-90 triangles (the numbers refer to the measure of the angles in the triangle).

title: Arc measure
description: Arc measure is equal to the arc's central angle. We'll explore this fact and solve some problems related to it.

title: Solving problems with similar & congruent triangles
description: You already saw how we can use similarity and congruence to find missing measures in triangles. Let's do the same now to solve more kinds of polygons, and more challenging problems!

title: Arc length (degrees)
description: Think about the relationship between central angle and arc length. This tutorial uses degrees not radians.

title: Solving modeling problems with similar & congruent triangles
description: Now that you are an expert with solving geometry problems using congruence and similarity, you are ready to solve some real-world problems!

title: Introduction to the trigonometric ratios
description: Learn what sine, cosine, and tangent are.

title: Introduction to conic sections
description: Conic sections are formed when you intersect a plane with a cone. In this tutorial, you will learn more about what makes conic sections special.

title: Features of a circle
description: Learn about the graphs of circles, and how their center and radius are represented algebraically.

title: Probability basics
description: Flip a quarter a hundred times. What's the probability that it will turn up heads? Tails? Even if we are unsure about whether something will happen, can we start to be mathematical about the "chances" of an event (essentially realizing that some things are more likely than others) occurring. This tutorial will introduce us to the tools that allow us to think about random events and the logic behind comparing, judging, and finding the probabilities of those events.

title: Introduction to radians
description: Most people know that you can measure angles with degrees, but only exceptionally worldly people know that radians can be an exciting alternative. As you'll see, degrees are somewhat arbitrary.

title: Solving for a side in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios
description: Learn how to find a side length in a right triangle when given one side length and one acute angle.

title: Standard equation of a circle
description: Learn about the standard form to represent a circle with an equation. For example, the equation (x-1)^2+(y+2)^2=9 is a circle whose center is (1,-2) and radius is 3.

title: Solving for an angle in a right triangle using the trigonometric ratios
description: Learn how to find an acute angle in a right triangle when given two side lengths.

title: Arc length (radians)
description: Think about the relationships between arc measures, central angles, and arc length in radians.

title: Modeling with right triangles
description: Solve real-world problems that can be modeled by right triangles, using trigonometry.

title: Expanded equation of a circle
description: Learn how to analyze an equation of a circle that is not given in the standard form. For example, find the center of the circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-5=0.

title: Trigonometric ratios & similarity
description: Learn how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.

title: Inscribed angles
description: We'll now dig a bit deeper in our understanding of circles by looking at inscribed angles and related properties.

title: Counting with combinations
description: You are already familiar with calculating permutation ("How many ways could 7 different people sit in 4 different seats?"). But what if you didn't care about which seat they sat in? What if you just cared about which 4 people were in the car? Or put another way, you want to know how many combinations of 4 people can you stick in the car from a pool of 7 candidates. Or how many ways are there to choose 4 things from a pool of 7? Look no further than this tutorial to answer your questions.

title: Focus & directrix of a parabola
description: A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the focus) and a line (called the directrix). In this tutorial you will learn about the focus and the directrix, and how to find the equation of a parabola given its focus and directrix.

title: Sine & cosine of complementary angles
description: Learn about the relationship between the sine of an angle and the cosine of its complementary angle, which is the angle that completes to 90.

title: Probability with counting, permutations, combinations
description: This tutorial will apply the permutation and combination tools you learned in the last tutorial to problems of probability. You'll finally learn that there may be better "investments" than spending all your money on the Powerball Lottery.

title: Inscribed shapes problem solving
description: Use properties of inscribed angles to prove properties of inscribed shapes, then apply these properties some fun problem solving!

title: Combining functions
description: Learn how to take two basic functions and combine them into a new function which is their sum, difference, product, or quotient.

title: Binomial theorem
description: Learn how to expand powers of binomial expressions (which are polynomial expressions with exactly two terms). This is done using the binomial theorem!

title: Multiplication rule for independent events
description: Whats the probability that three people were all born on the same day of the week? How likely is a basketball player to make three shots in a row? In this tutorial, well see that multiplying probabilities can be quite useful.

title: Understanding the binomial theorem
description: Now that you know how to use the binomial theorem in order to expand powers of binomial expressions, let's gain further insight into why this actually works!

title: Composing functions
description: Learn what function composition is, how to to work with composite functions, and how to find the formulas of the composition of two functions.

title: Multiplication rule for dependent events
description: Whats the probability of drawing two aces in a row from a deck of cards? Getting an ace on the first card changes the probability for the second card. This tutorial covers how we can deal with that when multiplying probabilities.

title: Advanced polynomial factorization methods
description: Learn more ways to factor polynomials with degree higher than 2.

title: Proving polynomial identities
description: Practice proving polynomial identities, using all the factorization and expansion methods you know.

title: Addition rule for probability
description: Whats the probability of picking a card and getting a jack or a heart? Whats the probability that someone owns a laptop or a smartphone? This tutorial will show how we can add probabilities to solve these types of problems.

title: Polynomial identities with complex numbers
description: Prove more polynomial identities, this time including complex numbers!

title: Area of inscribed triangle
description: This more advanced (and very optional) tutorial is fun to look at for enrichment.  It builds to figuring out the formula for the area of a triangle inscribed in a circle!

title: End behavior of polynomial functions
description: Learn about the end behavior of polynomial functions. End behavior is the way the function behaves as the input values grow infinitely positive or infinitely negative.

title: The constant e and the natural logarithm
description: Learn about a very special constant in math that has a pivotal role in the world of exponential and logarithmic function, the constant e.

title: Conditional probability
description: Given someone likes cheese, whats the probability they also like pizza? Knowing something can change what we know about the probability of something else. This tutorial on conditional probability covers how to find probability based on some known condition.

title: Modeling situations by combining & composing functions
description: Make use of knowledge in combining and composing functions, by modeling complex real-world situations.

title: Quadratic equations with complex numbers
description: Remember all these quadratic equations with "no real solution"? Well, it turns out those equations do have a solution, it's just a complex number! Solve a bunch of those here.

title: Simulation and randomness
description: Drawing names from a hat is fun, and so is calculating probability with formulas, but there are other options. This tutorial covers how we can use simulations and random digits to get samples and find probabilities.

title: Constructing regular polygons inscribed in circles
description: Have you ever wondered how people would draw a square, equilateral triangle or even hexagon before there were computers?  Well, now you're going to do just that (ironically, with a computer).  Using our virtual compass and straightedge, you'll construct several regular shapes (by inscribing them inside circles).

title: Expected value
description: Will a basketball player score more points over time from a two point shot or a three point shot? How much money can we expect to win back if we play the lottery? This tutorial on expected value will help us answer these types of questions.

title: Fundamental theorem of Algebra
description: You may already have noticed that quadratic equations always have a solution when including complex number solutions. It turns out this is true for any polynomial equation, of any degree! Learn about this and more, right here.

title: Constructing circumcircles & incircles
description: In our study of triangles, we spent a decent amount of time think about incenters (the intersections of the angle bisectors) and circumcenters (the intersections of the perpendicular bisectors).  We'll now leverage this knowledge to actually construct circle inscribed and circumscribed about a triangle using only a compass and straightedge (actually virtual versions of them).

title: Shifting functions
description: Learn how to transform functions so their graph is shifted horizontally or vertically. Learn how to find the equation of a function that is a shift of another function.

title: Simplifying rational expressions
description: Learn how to simplify rational expressions by canceling factors that are shared by the numerator and the denominator. Sometimes this calls for factoring the numerator and the denominator in various ways.

title: Finding zeros of polynomials
description: Use all the knowledge you have about polynomials to find their zeros (which are the input values that make the polynomial equal to zero).

title: Constructing a line tangent to a circle
description: Learn how to construct tangents to circles with certain conditions using compass and straightedge. For example, draw the tangent to a given circle that passes through a given point.

title: Stretching functions
description: Learn how to transform functions so their graph is stretched horizontally or vertically. Learn how to find the equation of a function that is a stretch of another function.

title: Introduction to logarithms
description: Learn how we define logarithms and use this definition in order to evaluate various logarithms. For example, evaluate log_2(8) as 3 by realizing that 2^3=8.

title: Zeros of polynomials and their graphs
description: Learn how to use the zeros of polynomials to draw a pretty good sketch of their graphs.

title: Introduction to inverses of functions
description: Learn what inverses of functions are, and gain some experience with them by finding the outputs of the inverse of a function given that function.

title: Finding inverse functions
description: Learn how to find the inverses of polynomials functions, radical functions, and rational functions.

title: Properties of logarithms
description: Learn about special properties of logarithms that help us rewrite logarithmic expressions in different equivalent (much like we use properties of exponents to rewrite exponential expressions!).

title: Verifying that functions are inverses
description: Learn how to check whether a pair of functions are the inverses of one another.

title: Introduction to symmetry of functions
description: You may already be familiar with types of symmetries of geometrical shapes. Learn how functions can be symmetrical too!

title: Adding & subtracting rational expressions
description: Learn how to add and subtract rational expressions. Like multiplication and division, this skill has a remarkable affinity to adding and subtracting fractions!

title: Determining whether a function is invertible
description: Learn about the conditions for a function to be invertible, and learn how to manipulate functions to make them invertible.

title: Symmetry of polynomial functions
description: Learn how to determine the symmetry of a polynomial function.

title: Change of base formula for logarithms
description: Learn how to rewrite any logarithmic expression in a different base. For example, rewrite log_2(3) as ln(3)/ln(2). This is very helpful for evaluating logarithms with a calculator, which only evaluates base-10 and base-e logarithms.

title: Law of sines
description: Learn about the Law of sines and how to use it in order to find missing side lengths and angles in general triangles.

title: Solving equations by graphing
description: Learn how to approximate the solution to any equation by using the power of graphs.

title: Exponential equations: logarithms
description: Learn how to solve any exponential equation by using logarithms. For example, solve 2^x=3 by calculating log_2(3).

title: Law of cosines
description: Learn about the Law of cosines and how to use it in order to find missing side lengths and angles in general triangles.

title: Systems of quadratic equations
description: Learn how to solve systems of two equations in two variables, where at least one of the equations is quadratic.

title: Nested fractions
description: Learn how to simplify rational expressions that contain further rational expressions within their numerators or denominators.

title: Solving general triangles
description: Use the power of trigonometry in order to solve various problems that involve triangles.

title: Solving exponential models
description: Learn how to solve word problems that require exponential equations.

title: Rational equations
description: Learn how to solve equations that have a rational expression, or a few of those.

title: Introduction to radians
description: Learn about radians, which are the official unit of measurement for angles in algebra (in contrast to degrees, which are used in geometry).

title: Graphs of exponential functions
description: Learn about the graphs of advanced exponential functions of the form y=a*b^(x+c)+d.

title: Interpreting the symmetry of algebraic models
description: Learn how to interpret graphs of modeling functions in terms of their context by considering their symmetry.

title: Interpreting the end behavior of algebraic models
description: Learn how to interpret graphs of modeling functions in terms of their context by considering their end behavior.

title: Interpreting the periodicity of algebraic models
description: Learn how to interpret graphs of modeling functions in terms of their context by considering their periodicity.

title: Unit circle definition of sine, cosine, & tangent
description: Learn how the trigonometric ratios are extended to all real numbers using algebra. Start solving simple problems that involve this new definition of the trigonometric functions.

title: Equation with two rational expressions (old example 2)
description: Sal solves the equation 5/(2x)-4/(3x)=7/18 by first finding the LCM (least common multiple) of 2x and 3x.

title: Equation with two rational expressions (old example 3)
description: Sal solves the following equation and eliminates the resulting extraneous solution: (x^2)/(x+2)=4/(x+2).

title: Direct and inverse variation
description: Learn about direct and inverse variation, which are two types of relationships between two quantities. Direct variation is simply a proportional relationship, but inverse variation is more complicated and interesting. Gain some experience with it before we dive deeper into the world of rational functions.

title: Comparing features of functions
description: Learn how to compare various features between two functions, each represented in a different way.

title: Graphs of sine, cosine, & tangent
description: Learn how the graphs of y=sin(), y=cos(), and y=tan() look, using the unit circle definition of the functions.

title: Logarithmic scale (optional)
description: Enrich your knowledge with some videos about logarithmic scales and how useful they are.

title: Basic trigonometric identities
description: Learn about very useful trigonometric identities that arise by considering different properties of the unit circle definition.

title: Multiplication intro
description: Welcome to the concept of multiplication.

title: Intro to adding negative numbers
description: Learn how to add negative numbers. By the end of this tutorial, you'll be solving problems like 4 + (-7) with ease!

title: Multiplying numbers with different signs
description: Find the product of numbers with different signs.

title: Addition within 100
description: Learn to add two-digit numbers like 37 and 49.

title: Multiplying and dividing negative numbers
description: Sal explains multiplying and dividing positive and negative numbers.

title: Why lattice multiplication works
description: Sal explains why lattice multiplication works.

title: Fractions intro
description: Learn what a fraction is and identify unit fractions.

title: Subtraction with regrouping within 1000
description: Learn how to subtract numbers like 363 - 259. These subtraction problems are a harder than the ones we've done before because they require regrouping (also called borrowing).

title: Fractions and whole numbers
description: Learn how to represent fractions as whole numbers and whole numbers as fractions.

title: Addition and subtraction missing value problems
description: Learn how to solve problems like "___ - 237 = 448" where you don't know one of the values in an addition or subtraction equation.

title: End behavior of rational functions
description: Learn about the ways in which rational functions behave as x approaches positive or negative infinity. This gets interesting Learn how to determine this behavior for any kind of rational function.

title: Basic sigma notation
description: Learn how to use and interpret sigma notation. Hint: It means take the sum!

title: Trigonometric values of special angles
description: Learn how to find the trigonometric values of some special angles without the use of a calculator.

title: Discontinuities of rational functions
description: Learn about the ways in which rational functions behave when their denominator is equal to zero. This gets interesting when vertical asymptotes are involved! Learn how to determine this behavior for any kind of rational function.

title: Pythagorean identity
description: Prove the Pythagorean trigonometric identity for all real numbers and use it in order to solve problems.

title: Finite arithmetic series
description: Learn how to evaluate and work with finite arithmetic series.

title: Samples and surveys
description: If we want to know something about a large group of people, we can take a sample and give them a survey. This tutorial introduces how that process works.

title: Graphs of rational functions
description: Combine your knowledge of intercepts, horizontal asymptotes, vertical asymptotes, and removable discontinuities, in order to analyze entire graphs of rational functions!

title: Introduction to amplitude, midline, & extrema of sinusoidal functions
description: Learn about very important features of sinusoidal functions: the amplitude and the midline. Learn how they relate to the extremum points of the function.

title: Observational studies and experiments
description: A new study shows that people who eat lobster regularly tend to live longer. That may be true, but it doesnt necessarily mean that eating lobster causes people to live longer. We could set up an experiment to find out if lobster is truly the cause. This tutorial covers the difference between observational studies and experiments.

title: Finding amplitude & midline from formula
description: Learn how to find the amplitude and the midline of the graph of a sinusoidal function from its formula. For example, find the amplitude and the midline of f(x)=3*sin(2x-1)+5.

title: Finite geometric series
description: Whether you are computing mortgage payments or calculating how many users your website will have after a few years,  geometric  series show up in life far more than you imagine.  This tutorial will review all the important concepts and more!

title: Period of sinusoidal functions
description: Learn about the period of sinusoidal functions: how it relates to extremum points and the midline, and how to find it from the formula of the function. For example, find the period of f(x)=3*sin(2x-1)+5.

title: Modeling with rational functions
description: See some examples of how rational functions and equations can come in handy when solving real-world word problems.

title: Binomial probability
description: If a basketball player has a 60% chance of making a free-throw, and hes going to shoot 10 free-throws, whats the probability that they make 5 or fewer free-throws? This tutorial on binomial probability will cover how to deal with problems just like this one.

title: Finite geometric series applications
description: Apply what you've learned about geometric series to model situations in some fun word problems.

title: Graphing sinusoidal functions
description: Learn how to draw the graph of sinusoidal functions. For example, draw the graph of f(x)=-2*cos(x)-7.
